abstract.p: Outlook for weekend college football games discussed; photo (M)

block.p: Today's KEY GAMES NO. 7 OKLAHOMA 5-0 NO. 14at KANSAS STATE 6-0

Finally, Kansas State faces a test and a smart passer in Josh Heupel. The Wildcats, fattening up on lesser teams, lead major colleges in scoring offense (51.3 points a game) and total defense (228.5 yards a game). They have outscored opponents, 308 to 61. Oklahoma's 63-14 runaway last Saturday over Texas was certainly an aberration, and Kansas State is a clear favorite.TV: ABC, 3:30 P.M.
NO. 12 AUBURN 5-1 NO. 18at FLORIDA 5-1

Rex Grossman, a redshirt freshman with a 64 percent completion average, 9 touchdowns and only 1 interception, will be Florida's quarterback again. The Gators' maligned defense stopped Louisiana State, and Auburn's potent offense gained only 164 yards in losing to Mississippi State.TV: CBS, 3:30 P.M.
NO. 16 OREGON 4-1 NO. 18at SOUTHERN CAL 3-2

Oregon, which upset Washington last time out with a good defense, faces a Trojan team whose offense was shaky in upset losses to Oregon State and Arizona. As Alex Holmes, Southern California's tight end, said dryly. ''I'm learning now that extreme criticism is a part of college football.''
OTHER GAMES EAST Syracuse (3-2) at Boston College (3-2) Two solid ground games in a Big East tossup. TV: ABC, Noon
Temple (3-3) at Rutgers (2-3) Their running games, squashed by Virginia Tech amd Miami, have a chance to breathe again.
Brown (3-1) at Princeton (1-3) Brown has the better offense and a sharper defense.
Yale (3-1) at Fordham (2-4) Fordham, which took a beating from Brown, faces more of the same.
Columbia (2-2) at Penn (2-2) Columbia's running and Penn's passing could make this a shootout.
SOUTH Vanderbilt (2-4) at No. 8 Georgia (4-1) Vanderbilt may not win a Southeastern Conference game all season.
No. 21 Mississippi (4-1) at Alabama (2-3) Beware of Alabama, even though flanker Freddie Milons, its big-play threat, is out with an injured knee.
TV: ESPN, 7 p.m. No. 24 Arkansas (4-1) at No. 22 South Carolina (5-1) After this, Arkansas faces Auburn, Mississippi, Tennessee and Mississippi State and could lose to all.
Southern Mississippi (4-1) at Tulane (3-2) Southern Mississippi has allowed one touchdown in the last four games.
Army (0-5) at East Carolina (3-2) East Carolina's offense, dormant against Memphis, should get well here.
MIDWEST Minnesota (4-2) at No. 4 Ohio State (5-0) Ohio State is sneaking up on the Nebraskas and the Virginia Techs. TV: ESPN2, Noon
Purdue (4-2) at No. 12 (tie) Northwestern (5-1) Northwestern leads the Big Ten with its no-huddle, four-receiver spread shotgun offense and Damien Anderson's running. TV: ESPN, Noon
Navy (0-5) vs. No. 19 Notre Dame (3-2) at Orlando, Fla. Notre Dame's offense should snap out of its deepest rut since 1963.
TV: CBS, Noon Indiana (2-3) at Michigan (4-2) Michigan is a good team that sometimes seems lost.
SOUTHWEST No. 3 Nebraska (5-0) at Texas Tech (5-1) Nebraska wins despite Texas Tech's good defense and passing game.

FAR WEST No. 10 U.C.L.A. (4-1) at California (1-4) Arizona State burned Cal for pass completions of 68, 54, 50 and 50 yards. No. 11 Washington (4-1) at Arizona State (4-1) Last week, Arizona State rolled up 566 yards, Washington 504.

Washington State (3-2) at No. 15 Arizona (4-1) Arizona's defense stopped Southern California with 10 yards rushing, 5 turnovers and 5 sacks. Texas (3-2) at Colorado (1-4) Texas can't be as bad as it looked against Oklahoma.

MISMATCHES Duke (0-5) at No. 6 Florida State (5-1) After losing to Miami, Coach Bobby Bowden of Florida State said, ''We're 5-1 and we've still got half the season to play. There's too much out there to still play for.'' Maryland (2-3) at No. 9 Clemson (6-0) Clemson's offense could end with a 600-yard day. TV: ESPN2, 6 p.m.
Rankings by the New York Times computer. All times are Eastern.

COLLEGE FOOTBALL
